instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.

threads.title: [SOLVED]Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead no greenlight no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi guys, I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> without <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

I donâ€™t know where start to fix. Seems like a short to ground but Im not sure.

I let you see my measures. 


<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> :  0.50v @ F7140 (Its pretty curious but that measure is going down so slowly)
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL>: 14.93v @ <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> Pin 1

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>: @ <CAPACITOR>C5120</CAPACITOR> 2.52v

On <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>

Pin 19 & 20 : 5.05v

Pin 2 : 14.71v

Resistance between pins 17 - 18 : 3.3 Ohms

Resistance betweens pins 27 - 28 : 20.0 Ohms

Pin 27 - 28 : 14.5 v

Helpme!

threads.title: [SOLVED]Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead no greenlight no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Why are you looking at PPBUS when PP3V42 is not even there. Resistance to GND on PP3V42? Liquid damage?

threads.title: [SOLVED]Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead no greenlight no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi, thx for helping me. i dont know how is first thats the reason why i looking ppbus first.
There is no liquid damage.
The resistance to ground on PP3V42 is 14.50 kOhms
In diode mode have 345

[SOLVED]Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead no greenlight no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
For instant personal support contact me in DM for the $500 per day "personal support plan".

Voltage on <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> pin 6? Voltage on L7095? Check board for corrosion?

threads.title: [SOLVED]Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead no greenlight no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Voltage on <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> pin 6: 14,71v
Voltage on L7095: 2,70v Both sides
The board don't have any corrosion. looks pretty well.

threads.title: [SOLVED]Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead no greenlight no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: 2.7V on L7095 is too low, check if feedback resistors are ok (<RESISTOR>R7095</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R7096</RESISTOR>), other than that , <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> is bad....

threads.title: [SOLVED]Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead no greenlight no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="aprendiz, post: 24068"]2.7V on L7095 is too low, check if feedback resistors are ok (<RESISTOR>R7095</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R7096</RESISTOR>), other than that , <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> is bad....[/QUOTE]

Thanks you aprendiz. i replace the <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>, and the <RESISTOR>R7095</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R7096</RESISTOR> and i get green and orange light. will test but i think this is done.
